statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Jason Kidd scored 33 points and Lucious Harris added 14 off the bench as the Nets controlled the fourth quarter en route to a 93-84 victory over the Miami Heat.
article.headline: Kidd calls his own number for 33 points
article.linkText: Kidd calls his own number, Nets take over Atlantic lead
article.story:
MIAMI (AP) -- Instead of a triple-double, Jason Kidd notched double-threes.
Kidd

Kidd scored 33 points and made two pivotal plays midway through the second half to lead the New Jersey Nets past the struggling Miami Heat 93-84 Friday night. Kidd had six rebounds and six assists, both below his season average, but sank 13 of 25 shots. "We like it when he gets others involved, but we obviously like the scoring,'' coach Byron Scott said. "The more he's aggressive on offense, the better off we are. He has a pretty good idea of what we need and when we need it.'' The Heat lost their fourth game in a row and fell to 1-6, their worst start in eight years. "We let it get away in certain areas,'' coach Pat Riley said. "It just adds up to another loss.'' The Nets took sole possession of first place in the Atlantic Division. They return home, where they're 5-0, to face unbeaten Dallas (9-0) on Saturday. "Something is going to have to give,'' Nets forward Kenyon Martin said. Martin left the game early in the fourth quarter after breaking his nose when he was accidentally hit in the face by Miami's Vladimir Stepania as they battled for a loose ball. Martin will likely be able to play against the Mavericks, Scott said. "He got his bell rung pretty good,'' Scott said. "I hope he can go. He looks to be OK.'' Rookie Caron Butler had a season-high 18 points for Miami, and Eddie Jones also scored 18. Travis Best, who had missed the past two games with a sprained ankle, added 16. Two heads-up plays by Kidd -- and two lapses by Miami -- let New Jersey score twice in the final seconds of the third quarter. Following a Miami free throw with 7.5 seconds left, Rodney Rogers threw a long pass to a streaking Kidd, who made a layup, drew a foul and hit the free throw. Kidd then lost a shoe as he stole Rasual Butler's inbound pass and threw the ball to Lucious Harris, who was fouled and sank both free throws for a 73-66 lead. "Disheartening and frustrating,'' Riley said. Those plays sparked a 13-2 Nets run to make it 81-68. Miami cut the margin to five three times in the final minutes but could get no closer. New Jersey outscored Miami by 19 points at the free-throw line. "They attack the basket and have big guys who crash the boards, and that makes it tough,'' Best said. The Nets sank their first six shots to take a 16-7 lead, then missed 16 of 20 to fall behind 36-29. The lead changed hands seven times in the third quarter before Kerry Kittles scored, stole a pass and made a dunk to put the Nets ahead 58-55. They led the rest of the way. New Jersey won despite shooting just 5-of-18 in the fourth quarter and 41 percent for the game. "Whether you shoot 60 percent or 30 percent, it's not going to be easy,'' Kidd said. "You have to keep working.'' Brian Grant, second in the NBA in rebounds, had 14 for Miami.

Game notes
Miami will play 10 games over the next 16 days. ... Alonzo Mourning, sidelined by a kidney ailment, said this week he wouldn't rule out a return to the Heat this season. But Riley doesn't expect such a comeback. "We have to move on, and we are,'' Riley said. "I just want him to get healthy.'' ... Riley says the Nets' fast break is the best he's seen since his Los Angeles Lakers' championship teams in the 1980s. ... The Nets are 5-0 when leading after one quarter.
